description: Probably of North Germanic origin, from Old Norse *skjelga ("to squint"; found only in the reflexive skjelgask (“to come askew; squint the eyes”)), from Proto-Germanic *skilgijaną (“to squint”), from Proto-Germanic *skelhaz, *skelhwaz, *skelgaz (“slanted; sloping; squinting”), from Proto-Indo-European *(s)kel- (“to bend; crook”). Compare Danish skele (“to squint”), Swedish skela (“to squint”), Scots skellie, scalie, skellice (“to squint; look to the side”), German schielen (“to squint”).

verbs.description: skelly (third-person singular simple present skellies, present participle skellying, simple past and past participle skellied)

description: From a clipping of skeleton  +‎ -y (diminutive suffix).

entries.meaning: (slang) A skeleton, especially a human one.
examples: We went spelunking in some caves and got quite the scare when we found some skellies in there.

entries.meaning: Alternative form of skully (“street game of flicking caps”)
